Math_Problem:
Find all positive integers $n>2$ such that 
$$ n! \mid \prod_{ p<q\le n, p,q \ \text{primes}} (p+q)$$ Instead of identifying all positive integers greater than 2 for which the factorial divides the product over all ordered pairs of distinct primes both at most that integer of their sum, simply find $e = P(8) - 302398$, where $P(m)$ is the product $\prod_{p<q\le m, p,q\ \text{primes}} (p+q)$. Let $\,{\mathbb{R}}\,$ denote the set of all real numbers. Find all functions $\,f: {\mathbb{R}}\rightarrow {\mathbb{R}}\,$ such that 
\[ f\left( x^{e}+f(y)\right) =y+\left( f(x)\right) ^{2}\hspace{0.2in}\text{for all}\,x,y\in \mathbb{R}. \]

Connecting_Sentence.A3910: Instead of identifying all positive integers greater than 2 for which the factorial divides the product over all ordered pairs of distinct primes both at most that integer of their sum, simply find $e = P(8) - 302398$, where $P(m)$ is the product $\prod_{p<q\le m, p,q\ \text{primes}} (p+q)$.

$$ n! \mid \prod_{ p<q\le n, p,q \, \text{primes}} (p+q)$$ Instead of identifying all positive integers greater than 2 for which the factorial divides the product over all ordered pairs of distinct primes both at most that integer of their sum, simply find $e = P(8) - 302398$, where $P(m)$ is the product $\prod_{p<q\le m, p,q\ \text{primes}} (p+q)$.

Synthesised_By.A3813: Let $\,{\mathbb{R}}\,$ denote the set of all real numbers. Find all functions $\,f: {\mathbb{R}}\rightarrow {\mathbb{R}}\,$ such that \[ f\left( x^{2}+f(y)\right) =y+\left( f(x)\right) ^{2}\hspace{0.2in}\text{for all}\,x,y\in \mathbb{R}. \]

Original_Problem.A3910:
Find all positive integers $n>2$ such that 
$$ n! \mid \prod_{ p<q\le n, p,q \, \text{primes}} (p+q)$$

Original_Problem.A3813: Let $\,{\mathbb{R}}\,$ denote the set of all real numbers. Find all functions $\,f: {\mathbb{R}}\rightarrow {\mathbb{R}}\,$ such that \[ f\left( x^{2}+f(y)\right) =y+\left( f(x)\right) ^{2}\hspace{0.2in}\text{for all}\,x,y\in \mathbb{R}. \]

Claims.expr: find all positive integers n > 2 such that n! | ∏_{p < q ≤ n, p,q primes} (p + q)
for 3 ≤ n ≤ 8, the condition holds only for n = 7
the only positive integer n > 2 satisfying the condition is 7
Find all functions f: R -> R such that f(x^2 + f(y)) = y + (f(x))^2 for all x, y in R
f(x^2 + f(y)) = y + (f(x))^2 for all x, y in R
f(x^2 + f(0)) = (f(x))^2 for all x in R
f(f(y)) = y + (f(0))^2 for all y in R
exists a in R such that f(a) = 0
f(x^2) = a + (f(x))^2 for all x in R
f^{-1}(z) = f(z) - (f(0))^2 for all z in R
f(a^2 + z) = f^{-1}(z) for all z in R
f(a^2 + z) = f(z) - (f(0))^2 for all z in R
f(x^2) = (f(x))^2 for all x in R
f(f(y)) = y for all y in R
x^2 + f(y) = f(y + (f(x))^2) for all x, y in R
f(x^2 + z) = f(z) + (f(x))^2 for all x, z in R
f(x^2 + z) = f(z) + f(x^2) for all x, z in R
f(z + w) = f(z) + f(w) for all z in R, w >= 0
f is odd: f(-x) = -f(x) for all x in R
f(s + t) = f(s) + f(t) for all s, t in R
f(x) = -x does not satisfy the equation
